segments.pli: Aṅguttara Nikāya 9
5. Sāmaññavagga
43. Kāyasakkhīsutta
“‘Kāyasakkhī, kāyasakkhī’ti, āvuso, vuccati.
segments.en: “Reverend, they speak of a person called ‘personal witness’.

segments.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā”ti?
segments.en: What is the personal witness that the Buddha spoke of?”

segments.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi … pe … paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: “First, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures … enters and remains in the first absorption.

segments.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
segments.en: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

segments.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena. (1)
segments.en: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the personal witness in a qualified sense.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā … pe … dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …
segments.en: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption …

segments.pli: tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ …
catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
segments.en: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

segments.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena. (2–4.)
segments.en: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the personal witness in a qualified sense.

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

segments.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
segments.en: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

segments.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā pariyāyena … pe …. (5–8.)
segments.en: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the personal witness in a qualified sense. Furthermore, take a mendicant who enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness … the dimension of nothingness … the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception …

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti.
segments.en: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.

segments.pli: Yathā yathā ca tadāyatanaṃ tathā tathā naṃ kāyena phusitvā viharati.
segments.en: They meditate directly experiencing that dimension in every way.

segments.pli: Ettāvatāpi kho, āvuso, kāyasakkhī vutto bhagavatā nippariyāyenā”ti. (9)
segments.en: To this extent the Buddha spoke of the personal witness in a definitive sense.”

segments.pli: Dutiyaṃ.

sections.title: “Reverend, they speak of a person called ‘personal witness’.…

suttaplex.blurb: The Buddha speaks of a “direct witness’, that is, someone who personally has thorough  and proficient experience of the different meditation states.
